commentBody: Another super-fast Friday, and a personal best for me at 7:30—felt more like a Tuesday, but a fun one. I loved GOODKARMA.
This seemed awfully smooth & easy. Seems like the trend to make Fridays more accessible for newcomers is continuing. I get that, but please please the old pros too.
Another quick Friday. Enjoyed some of the solves, though, even though the time went by quickly.

Lots of fun, fast and easy, and I liked the references to Valentine's Day. I found that I knew almost nothing in the SE corner, but  worked with what I had to finish it off. I mean, how many 6-letter countries that start with U are there? [rhetorical question] I won't remember the name of the dish, but maybe I'll remember it's made with green bananas.
Happy Pitchers and Catchers report to spring training day!

Wild to see a reference to my favorite childhood author, Lloyd Alexander - I genuinely thought that was a lost name.  I still love 'The High King'.  In general, I'm staunchly on the side of the creators/editors of the Times puzzle, but it has been disappointing that the last few weekends have featured harder-than-average-Wednesday puzzles.  This happens occasionally, but this feels like a sustained funk.
Quick Friday.  New PB. Great fun.

This one moved quite fast for me, at almost 2 minutes faster than the Thursday one.  I did notice how our constructor snuck her name in there at 39A.  Spelled "correctly", as she says, as the name derives from Hebrew, which has a ה, or a he, at the end.  This letter is a precursor to H and generally has the H sound, except at the end of words, much like in English.  But since Hebrew is usually written without vowels, the ה serves to indicate that there is a vowel sound at the end of the word, so it is a useful letter indeed.

On the other hand, it's altogether silent in English, and exists for etymological purposes only.

Complete respect for 50A, Futbol Stadium Cry.

What a great way to point out her puzzle didn't use OLE ANYWHERE.
My best time for a Friday. Fun puzzle to do before bed.

Wow!  A singing valentine - SO SWEET, thanks Sarah and friends.

The challenge is on, constructors!  Videos of yourselves doing an aria, perhaps?  Or some interpretive dance?  Standup comedy?  Yoga? (we know one such person).  Let’s see what you’ve got!
Going to be a lot of Friday PBs on this one. 3:44 here... going to be a long while before that gets topped.

Nice clueing and fill, but this was far too easy. Like others, I finished quickly, with my time being about 55% of my average.

6/10.
Clean, straightforward...lacked wit and grit.
I enjoyed the rectitudinousness of this puzzle.

There was a ton of GOODKARMA for me in this puzzle.  I had just finished watching the movie Monuments Men, 10 minutes before the puzzle dropped.  Great cast, mediocre movie, about the effort to recover art looted by the Nazis toward the end of WWII.  One of the major pieces recovered was JAN Van Eyck’s Ghent alter piece.  Then, the puzzle gave me Klimt’s THEKISS, a copy of which adorns a photo album my wife gave me and which sits on a bookshelf right behind the chair where I was sitting to do the puzzle.

And how appropriate for a Valentine’s Day puzzle to have WOOS cross CANOODLE?  Although I must admit CANOODLE is one of the select group of words that I have an aversion to, and can’t imagine ever using IRL.

There were plenty of good clues (I liked a little unwell for MEDIUMRARE) and several general knowledge questions that I didn’t know, like the national dish of UGANDA, but nothing that held me back too long.  All in all a fine puzzle.

Awesome puzzle! Technically, Catholics and Lutherans have respect for God’s name as the second
commandment. Other Christian denominations and Judaism have the prohibition mentioned here.
What a lovely singing Valentine! Thanks Sarah and Wordplay!

Loved the singing Valentine greeting 😍🥰 Didn’t mind an easier Friday - plenty of fun Valentine clues squeezed in there to elicit a smile 😃 Thank you, Sarah

Happy Valentine’s Day, Crosslandia ❤️

I thought this was just about right for a Friday. I had a lot of misdirects—WEBSITE instead of WARRIOR (love that clue) OLE instead of GOL, ROKER instead of DENTE, RWANDA before UGANDA. Love the callout to LLOYD Alexander although for me it was The Black Cauldron. Not a great fan of CATCHFEELINGS as a marquee entry, seems a little clunky but maybe it’s just an idiom I’m not familiar with. Finally anyone else see a 5 letter word starting with F for “bad things to blow” and immediately  come up with something that didn’t pass the smell test?

"Sara(h), you're the poet in (our) heart(s), never change and don't you ever stop" bringing us your wonderful crossword puzzles (with apologies to Stevie Nicks for taking liberty with the lyrics.)

I always appreciate a grid wherein the unknowns are inferable, needing only a few or even just one letter to break through.  It also delights me when the fill is varied and interesting such as in this one.

Many thanks for this puzzle, Sarah, and to the barbershop quartet for a stupendous Valentine's Day greeting (with honorable mention for the crossword garment!)

A Happy Valentine's wish to all in Crosslandia - editors, constructors, columnists, and my dear commenters - with all my love, and many thanks for the joy you bring.
loved this puzzle! super smooth sailing. wishing everyone a lovely day

I enjoyed fresh takes on some of the clues such as 50A (almost put in the usual corrida cry).
Made me 38D at 26D, very well done!

Thank you

This grid seems tailor-made for John Ezra to give us a sequel to his steamy “Atlas Stripped” novella from Tuesday.  Perhaps CANOODL(ING) KENDO WARRIORs this time around?  But revolutionaries can’t get sidetracked . . . 

Crossword Revolution Day 24:  SARAH

The novel “Ragtime” holds a special place in my heart, as it got me through a tough day in a hospital waiting room over 40 years ago. 
 If you were compiling a list of novels to read to understand the United States, this would be at or near the top of the list.  And, of course, Audra McDonald is an American treasure.  So, thanks SARAH for including your name and cluing it in a way that helps move the CR forward.  

A Crosswords Saved the Day ™ production.

Never thought of "a little unwell" as potential crossword fodder because we jokingly called our rain barrel the unwell. When the kids put out mason jars to measure rainfall, we called them "little unwells" (that's how we roll at J-ez's crib) -- neither kid grew up to be a scientist. But MEDIUM RARE is an even better answer. Chef's (the) kiss! What did we do with the water in the rain barrel? Every so often I would happen by it, on the side of our house and stop to peer into its clear depths. It was a true wooden barrel with staves of oak, belted with iron, picked up at a flea back in the nineties. I stopped up the many leaks with some tarry goop that turned the inside greenish black. Then I would push up my sleeves and use both hands to give my face a good rain rinse, with its scents of ozone, cloud and Pittsburgh (coal, coke, steak & fries atop your salad, kolbasi, smoky sweat) -- it woke me to the core. Then I'd wrestle the barrel to its side; the water eagerly gushed down the driveway. Months, maybe even a year would pass before I'd do it again. --a rich puzzle spiced with unusual words. As others have said, GOL was a great subtle mockery of our steady diet of OLEs. Nose rings, the afterlife, Enya, Lama, false idols, tents & the Talmud gave this puzzle a distinctly pan-mythic ancient religion new-age vibe which I found charming, like the Sheik of Arabee. Here's a Valentine to the law: https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2025/02/13/us/doc-annotation-letter-to-bondi.html

Nice, and very quick.  Probably too easy but I don't feel like complaining.  (You're welcome. :) )

It was so warming to see a 3 letter stadium cheer OTHER than our good friend you know who.  Great change of pace.

Seems like the easiest of the week since Monday.  What a change from last week.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler

I almost never diss a puzzle. 
I HATED this one, although I seem to be in the deep minority so maybe it’s me.
But NOSERING?? KITTENCHOW??!!
Weak.
A fun, smooth, bubbly Friday puzzle. Much of it was in my wheelhouse so it went quickly, but I really enjoyed it.

A fun puzzle to solve. Appreciated all the nods to the unstated theme. TOL what the eye test chart is called. And like Deb, did not know that ONE LOVE was initially a Ska song. And as Joni sang, In France they kiss on main street amour, mamma, not cheap display. https://youtu.be/sEgcHrbyTgk?si=QbgsU3eB3YWoyR1P

I'm pretty sure there are going to be a lot of "too easy" comments here, and they may be as right as you can be about something that is neither wrong nor right.  

Anyway, I've been thinking about a comment about going back to 1993, when the puzzles were so much harder.

But I wonder...isn't a 1993 puzzle probably easier in 1993 than it will be in 2025?  Puzzles obviously don't exist outside a context.

So is it even possible to evaluate a 1993 puzzle for difficulty now?  Or a puzzle now for how hard it's going to be in 2057?
Sorry but this crossword contained way way too many trivia clues, and can we figure out a different clue for OLE?
Thank you for the barbershop quartet interlude! I really enjoyed that. And the puzzle was also a lot of fun. Thanks again, Sarah.

The Prydain Chronicles is one of my five all-time fantasy series (rounded out by Lord of the Rings, Harry Potter, Narnia, and His Dark Materials). If GRRM ever gets around to finishing ASOIAF, I'll reevaluate that list. Hopefully Disney will get around to making ac live action series of Prydain sooner, rather than later

That was great! I really enjoyed the solve. I loved GOODKARMA for [clean energy?] and of course MEDIUMRARE for [a little unwell?].  I had MEDIUM___E and still needed 2 more crosses before seeing rare. 

FALSEIDOL was a gimme but I really enjoyed seeing it in a crossword. Well, not exactly a gimme... there's a Ten Commandments song from my childhood that I had to sing in my head for it. 

I was annoyed with the [unrealistic claim on the packaging of a kids toy] until I got the NOMESS answer. That combo has my utmost respect, and I don't even have kids lol.
Probably my fastest Friday solve ever, so I’m not complaining.
Good Wednesday puzzle.

I have not looked at today's puzzle yet, but I have comments about a puzzle from 2006, which I've been working on for a while, it's really hard. For me, anyhow.

Did I mention that it's super hard? And that I'm probably not going to be able to complete it?

Anyhow, earlier tonight I was sitting in a favorite local restaurant bar, waiting for my friend, and working on this 2006 puzzle. I'm a regular at this place and my server is a regular at this place for many years. So while I was working on this,  he approached, and  one of the clues was, " Home bartenders tool." It was five letters and I knew it started with a T.

Knowing that dear Dan is a server and a bartender, I asked him...  Bless his heart, he looked at it intently... He couldn't think of anything but he said he think about it... and also ask the bar manager... 

He came back a little while later with my martini, no need to mention that it was a gin martini... Hahaha... And said to try tongs number one, or, tulip.

Huzzah! It was tongs! I have never in a million years would have thought of that!! 

I mean, It's technically a cheat, but screw that, huzzah!!

Also this puzzle includes the answer SAPID for like pleasing the palate or some such. Seriously!? Beyond my pay grade. Har! 

All right, I think I'll sleep for a while and then sometime soon I'll be back to work on today's puzzle. 

Sapid....   🤯🤯🤯🤯🤯
First Friday with no look-ups whatsoever! Loved it

"Your parents pay you to clean your room?"
"Yeah, I get a tidy sum!"

("I thought I'd also get paid...must have been a mess-understanding.")

What a weird puzzle. Apparently it was very easy - but only for those who knew all the names, maybe? Because there were so many proper noun and trivia clues! I knew some of the answers, but I needed 10 or 15 lookups, too. Having googled all the arcana, I solved in Wednesday time (and 3 minutes faster than last week's "Tuesday").
Great puzzle. As many have noted, the 'medium rare' is a thing of beauty.

Pretty easy for a Friday, although I had a couple of missteps that I had to correct. Initially I had good vibes instead of GOOD KARMA but the crosses took care of that and a few trivia bits. Amusing and not too confusing.

There's a whisper down the line at 9:39
When the crossword's ready to drop,
Saying "Sarah where is Sarah has she gone to hunt an error?
We must find her or the puzzle can't start."
All the editors and the proofers and the web edition’s users
They are searching high and low,
Saying "Sarah where is Sarah if she’s off singing a capella
Then the crossword just can't go."
At 9:42 then the signal's nearly due
And the solvers are frantic for the drop—
Then Sarah will appear and she'll saunter to the rear:
She’s been busy in the costume shop!

Really enjoyed this puzzle. Breezed through some of the modern colloquial fill with satisfying lucky guesses, but got stuck in a few areas. 

Felt rectitudinous for a Friday, IMO.

¡Olé!
Fun one
Another Friday yawn - a lookup puzzle. Obscure clues, niche trivia which also crosses.

Sorbet is what comes to mind with this puzzle. Very refreshing.  For instance, I was so used to ole that I was shocked and pleased when GOL was used.

I put some answers in on the first pass saying, “No way is it going to be” CATCHFEELINGS or TAKESTHEL. When the crossings fell into place and started chanting “Wheelhouse! Wheelhouse!” (Yes, IMDOINGOK — just the excitable type 🤣)

Then I pressed my luck too far and entered bsure for 35A. Please tell me someone gets that reference. If you do, you can feel free to tell me how ridiculous and far fetched it was 🤣.

Sleep APNEA was, unfortunately, a gimme. GOODKARMA, ONELOVE and many more just tumbled into place with no lookups.  

As a superfan of Bewitched, which I have watched on reruns all my life, I was hoping for something show related for 59A.  My one cat’s name is Samantha. I would have named my tomcat Darrin but I find that character odious 😤. If I can break through the two-cat limit imposed by my husband, I’d have Tabitha, Serena, Endora, Maurice, Dr Bombay and, of course, Uncle Arthur 😂.  So clearly, KITTENCHOW was a breeze.

I enjoyed the puzzle and the musical treat, SARAH!
Love the video! Thanks! Made my day.
Well that was a fun one, I love it when the solve gives me the feeling of satisfaction that one only gets from eating a good steak - MEDIUMRARE of course.

18A, bad things to blow. Oh my, Ms. Amlen. I don't know about anyone else, but my mind was nowhere near the gutter on this one. My first thought was noses, but if you've got a cold, it's good to blow those. Heavens.
I had hoped for a heart-shaped puzzle or hearts in the squares. Something more romantics. . . .otherwise it was  good puzzle.

For 54A I had BLOT which shows you the sort of clot I am. 
PS. I loved all the spin dry humour in this one.
Sweet!

Other than a brief flirtation with ole and FALSE gods (is there another type?), my solve was smooth and quick.

Thanks for the singing Valentine, sarah.  Beautiful harmony.

For me, it was just ok. Maybe a few too many quote clues. I always forget what the difficulty for the days are except Monday is easy and the weekends usually bring me pain, but I think maybe it was a little simple for a Friday? There hasn't been a rebus for a while, which is never something I thought I'd complain about

Strands Thread: 


          Strands #348
          “Will you be my valentine?”
           🟡🔵🔵🔵
            🔵🔵🔵

Express no spoilers please until after the View All Replies button. 

Yes!

This puzzle is like its own little ROMCOM. 

it runs the gamut from CATCH FEELINGS, WOOS, and CANOODLE to the lovely symmetry of THE KISS and ONE LOVE to AMOUR and finally the I DOS. 

SO SWEET! What's not to love? 

Thanks, Sarah. Happy Valentine’s Day.

In some traditions the 2nd Commandment is, Thou shalt not brag about solve time.  

Indeed, many scholars have concluded that Moses solved with one finger on his tablet.
Thank you, Sarah, and thank your Familiar Sounding friends, for the SO SWEET singing valentine!  I needed that.

Disappointed that I am not a member of the easy Friday club today – my solve time was just a hair under average. I had a hard time gaining any momentum when I started the puzzle last night so I picked it up again early this morning and was able to finish.

I hope Sarah has started a trend where constructors submit a video that entertains us.

Well, the good vibes are just flowing! 

Because our anniversary is a couple days before,
Valentine’s Day isn’t a thing in 
our house, now that the kids are grown.

So it was really, truly fun to be serenaded!
And right after this love-centric ode to puzzling!

It felt like that, to me.
Canoodling, wooing, amorous solving which
is the One Love we all have in common.

Happy Friday all!

As I struggled with the first half of the grid I thought I was in for a tough Friday. ONE LOVE saved me. Huge Ska fan, it melds well with Punk. Memories of sneaking out to Blues parties as a teen. Highly illicit get togethers with imported Jamaican Ska discs and ‘tobacco’. 
 ENYA a shoe-in as the credits song to the LOTR trilogy films. Everything else followed.

I found the clue for 26D a bit odd, though I can see I’m in a minority there. It just felt clunky to me. Neck before NOSE, several unknown names and a completely unknown phrase held me up for a while TAKE THE L?? I mean, I can work out what it means, but do people actually say that? 
GOL instead of the eternal ole was nice to see.

All together a Good Friday offering, thank you Sarah. Sadly my uptight British soul would shrivel and die of embarrassment if someone sent me a sung Valentine. Or anything sung to my face tbh. Just can’t deal. I know, I know. I need therapy.

Nice Friday puzzle. Not all that easy for me, of course, but just had a good time working it all out. Lots of nice 'aha' moments when something finally dawned on me. 

Valentine's day led me to a really unusual puzzle find. I'll put that in a reply. 

...
An easy but enjoyable puzzle. The musical Valentine's message was delightful!

It was a bit slow-going for me. Never saw the word CATCH associated with FEELINGS or heard the term TAKESTHEL, so I had to rely on a lot of crosses to get those answers.

For some unknown reason, though, ALF came to me in a flash, though I never watched the show. I did know ONE LOVE, and I love it when a song lyric makes the title pop into my head. Unfortunately, it happens rarely!

My favorite clue was [A little unwell], though it evoked memories of my mother telling me that that was the term used when a girl/got her period, i.e. being unwell. Thank heavens that's not used anymore! 

I did manage to finish without any lookups, so now I can look forward to Saturday's offering.

Well, nice to have an easier Friday after I got myself all tied up in my shoe laces Thursday:)

One mistake I had for false ad about kids’ toys was
NO MeDS for NO MESS. I know: What was I thinking? 

The A capella video was very well done and a lot of fun! Loved Sarah’s Xword tee shirt, too. Have a Happy Vday 25, All!

To Sarah's musical wish, "I hope you enjoy this puzzle," I reply "I do! I do!" (IDOS) What a wonderful Valentine's Day-themed themeless puzzle! Taran! Princess Eilonwy! Fflewdur Fflam! Gurgi! Doli! When my original Yearling paperbacks wore out from innumerable rereadings, I invested in a hardback one-volume omnibus--about five years ago. I can't read the passage in *The High King* in which Fflewdur burns his harp, without crying. By way of a musical Valentine Day's offering, here's "Garden of Love's Sleep," from *Turangalîla-Symphonie* by Olivier Messaien, one of the greatest orchestral works of the 20th c., IMHO. Here performed by the Royal Concergebouw Orchestra under Riccardo Chailly, with Jean-Yves Thibaudet on piano, and some really weird mathematical graphics (what the?): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SO1a2NQoYaA Bonus points if you can guess what other entry this refers to!

If someone woos you, does it make you feel woozy?

If someone canoodles you, is it chicken soup for your soul?

If we don’t gripe about a really fast Friday puzzle,
is that good karma?

Love the singing Valentine and the bonus of a themed Friday! 

I also liked that the stadium cry wasn't "ole" for a change.

Thanks, Sarah!

It’s hard enough to make a 70-word crossword that has hardly a whiff of junk, harder to make one both clean and lively, and even harder to make one that’s scrubbed and vibrant, and infused with a theme.

Enter today’s offering, which Sarah’s notes say is filled with romantic references for this romantic day.  And she pulls it off without even a touch of strain or desperation.  That requires skill and talent, and here it is on display in her first solo NYT themeless.

I was won over the moment I uncovered TIDY SUM.  Truly, I stopped for a moment after filling it in, warmly smiled, and thought, “Oh. Now. That’s gorgeous.”  It is SO SWEET to brush with beauty any time, but especially on Valentine’s day, and that, on top of this lovey-dovey-imbued grid, got me feeling just right.  

Thank you, Sarah, for coming up with the idea for this amorous puzzle, for following through with it, and for nailing it!
a fun, breezy puzzle today. looks like we all got juked by 50A 🤣

At first I thought there was too many culture references, but I managed to get everything with the cross clues! I was a joy to CATCHFEELINGS with this puzzle! (Except for the N/M typo I made on MEDIUM RARE that completely disappeared and stumped me for a good 5 minutes and turned a 12 min solve into a 17) 😭

I also found this puzzle a fairly quick solve in around half my usual time. But I found myself staring at the competed grid in admiration. Almost no filler! Bravo. Auspicious start to the solving weekend (long weekend for me in Ontario with Family Day on Monday)
Ragtime with Audra McDonald  and a cast of wonderful singers is wonderful. Thank you.
This is a very nice puzzle with intriguing clues and no tricky stuff.

A few comments below, I posted a youtube link to an orchestral work by Olivier Messaien. From another far corner of the polygon of my musical tastes, here is "39t Detroit"*, sung at the Liberty Baptist Church of Henegar, Alabama: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T0udlavs58o (Although--O false memory!--the lyrics are "each cursèd idol," not "false idol.") *In Sacred Harp singings, the leader "calls" the song by name and page number--"Detroit, on page 39, at the top half of the page." Everyone gets an opportunity to lead and gets to call the song, and songs are generally sung only once at any given singing; hopefully, you get your turn at leading before someone else beats you to your favorite song. My go-to is "209 Evening Shade."
Thank you Sarah for brightening my day with a great solve and a barbershop Valentine :) Sending you sweet valentines this morning in thanks !
Thank you Ms. Sinclair for this Valentine treat. My "One Love" returns from NYC this afternoon. "Canoodling" just might break out!
This one was a gem!  CANOODLE? TAKESTHEL?MEDIUMRARE? Beautiful— thank you!

Thou shalt have no other GODS before me....Thou shall make no  graven IMAGES...  I think IDOLs were understood to be FALSE...
It's nice to revisit some archaic language in the face of a lot of Noob Speak...like CATCH FEELINGS (in lieu of measles? Mumps? Rubella?  Because I think they'll be coming back, actually. Do worms have an AFTERLIFE?)

Happy VD, everyone!  I guess the easier-than-normal puzzle was our Valentine treat, eh?  I made Springerle cookies imprinted with love birds and roses.  Mmmmm  Love the scent, the taste, the pre-bite-prettiness!
Huge thanks to this puzzle for introducing me to the original ska version of “One Love” - gonna be listening to this all day!
"Takes the L" is new to me! When I was a kid, before rich hipsters swarmed Williamsburg, this might have made sense, but ...

This started out tough and was fairly daunting. As most of the cultural stuff was unknown to me, I didn't have any real gimmes.

I got Micky Mantle's entry only because of the number of squares.

I eat chocolate and read ingredients on the stuff I eat, so that got me three letters with no effort. And then Enya and Eke showed up, what a surprise!  :-D

But by playing detective I slowly gained toeholds that then cascaded into significant fills.

So for an unhip, culturally clueless, previous generation guy who knows a bit about linguistics and likes to puzzle things out,  this took about 25 minutes. 

I doubt that is brag-worthy, but that's not my point. As a data/analysis guy, I figure the construction team might appreciate some anecdotal information on how the puzzle worked.
'One Love', by the man who make Reggae famous, Bob Marley - is NOT ska.

You canoodle, but you may not.

I loved this themeful themeless puzzle! 

Still trying to decide if ["Willing to join our endeavor?"] was meant to be part of the theme.
Re: today's mini, TIL that you can figure out the length of each month using your knuckles. Had no idea that was a thing. I learned the "30 days hath November" poem when I was a kid. Didn't everyone?

Was I the only one who had GOOD CARBS for "Clean energy?" Instant karma's gone and got me today. Other than that, it was a PLUM.

I didn't see the Barbie movie; does Ken practice KENDO in his Mojo Dojo? (The way of Ken?)
Takes the l? Was lost on me. Otherwise great puzzle!

A smooth, easy, and flowy Friday. Great fill and cluing from top to bottom, with some lovely thematic answers for V-day.

I hope today, everyone finds love—whether a secret AMOUR or your longtime ONE LOVE, may today be a day of people who CATCH FEELINGS watching ROM COMs. Many lovers today will share a huge moment—THE KISS and perhaps even a few I DOS. Some will just CANOODLE while their partner WOOS them with hugs and chocolates. And some will choose today to love themselves, settling in for some VITAL self-care with NO MESS, and I think that’s SO SWEET too.

As for me, I’M DOING OK and I hope all of you fellow puzzlers are, too. Let today be a reminder to love everyone, including ourselves. ❤️

Love!

Good morning. 
Excellent cluing and a really fun fill. Lots of Valentine gems without being overbearing. 
"So close"...
Laugh of the day: "NO MEds" made perfect sense to me at 2D crossing with EdT. 
Have a great day with your loves! (And happy "national singles awareness day" to the rest of us.)

Yet another riff on today's delightful puzzle:

In some religious traditions, the prohibition against false idols is rolled in to Commandment #1; such is the Roman Catholic tradition which was the inspiration for Polish director Krzysztof Kieślowski's film series *Dekalog*.  In the first of the ten films, a scientist uses computer modelling to assure his young son that the ice on a near-by lake will support three times the boy's weight.

In this case, the False Idol is Science.

At the moment, we are happily snowed in at our place in Northern Michigan, on a small inland lake. We have enough food, and I have the crossword. The lake is Christmas-card beautiful--frozen over and snow covered--and will certainly support the weight of a skier; of an ice-fisher; of a snowmobiler.

Or not.
Love the video message from the creator. More of that, please!

Couldn't ask for a better themeless crossword for Valentine's Day. Thanks for the singing Valentine Sarah, that was SO SWEET! 

Tomorrow I'm going to celebrate 1/2 price Chocolate Day. 🍫
I don’t typically play for time, but today was a Friday PR at 6:13
Is there a column for the Mini? I totally have a spoiler I’m dying to say for today. 😀
The recent Friday puzzles have been a bit too easy but still enjoyable
Good puzzle, but should probably have been a Wednesday.

SO SWEET to have a constructor serenade us! 

I had ANTES instead of TENTS for quite a while 😉
17 proper nouns... i guess this is just becoming trivia now.

Despite finding the first few clues impenetrable at first, count me in with those who found this one on the easier side (about a third of my average solve time for a Friday and only a couple of minutes above my PB). However, the sans serif font—I usually solve in the iPad app—did render 35A a bit harder than possibly intended: I wasn’t sure without crosses if the clue had to do with stochastic parrots or with the Italian contraction of a preposition and definite article.

happy day to me- i got my best Friday time! interesting how "of the moment" puzzles can be. I was recently working on some NYT Saturday puzzles from a book published a few years ago, and it is so hard, and I'm doing okay at Saturdays after many years of trying

Happy Valentine's Day.  

💐♥️💐♥️💐♥️💐♥️💐♥️💐♥️💐♥️💐♥️💐♥️💐♥️

The Emus ate my comment  last night, but happy Valentine's Day to them too anyway.

FALSEgods and ole really hung me up in the southeast. When things like AGAME and INATRANCE didn't seem to work, I first took them out instead of my two wrong answers, as I wracked my brain to remember the Futurama name. I watched a season or two a very long time ago, but could not place the name until I eventually decided to take out gods and ole...  but I got there. 

Otherwise, I was surprised to sail through as fast as I did. It felt fun and lively though, and it'll give me more time to stare blankly at the remainder of the puzzle from a 2006 Saturday, that I've been working on and off for hours and hours.  

Like many, I really enjoyed the clue for MEDIUMRARE... A little unwell? Ha! 

Cheers to the weekend, all!

The Futurama character's full name is Turanga Leela; her parents are Turanga Morris and Turanga Munda: like Hungarians and Koreans, sewer mutants place the family name before the given name.

But the puzzle was great.  Did it in well under average time.

That makes up for the mini today.  I almost always am under 1 minute, usually under 30 seconds.  Today it took me over 2 minutes!  Oscar nominated movie I didn't know.  Publication that I didn't know the tag-line for.  Kevin who?  Just not my wheelhouse, as they say.....

Happy Valentine's Day.  DH and I are ordering pizza.  Not the night to go out to a restaurant.  Too many people!  I love him truly, but not enough to put up with the crowds.

Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
Note to the reader: the previous bro comment was a callback to yesterday's crowd favorite by another poster @BK

@P.

Cmon who can type that fast? My best on Monday is about 4-5 minutes and that’s filling in everything as fast as I can.
@SP It's not really about typing speed, it's about reading speed. Also, I don't know if you play on your phone rather than a computer, but that's a easy 90 second handicap right there.

@SP 

My best time ever was a few seconds more than BC's, but I wouldn't be surprised if I surpass it some day.  The keys to super low times are, in no particular order:

1. Being a good touch typist from the olden days when the typing teacher insisted you couldn't look at your hands.

2. Being able to read clues for the next entry while typing in the previous one.

3. Using a desktop computer.  Not a phone.  Not a tablet.  Not even a laptop.  I've solved on all of those, but the only way to get down to under three minutes is to sit up razor-straight at a desktop.

4. Shut out all distractions.  If all you need is less than three minutes, this is usually doable at some point in the day.  Mine is when the Mrs. goes to bed before I do.

5. And of course, experience.  This only happens if you answer practically every clue correctly immediately the first time around, and for the few you don't know, to skip immediately.  

I don't really speed solve, although I occasionally try to pick up the pace on an early-week puzzle when I get off to a good start.  My times are usually achieved in an unrushed manner.  But I have done a couple of Minis in 8 seconds.

Hope this helps!

@Francis super true.  I have been working on the first puzzle (from 1942) off and on for more than a year. The shift in context is so huge, "easy" clues feel impossible.

The 90s era is more accessible to me at least (among other things my wife & I had a stretch in those years where we did the puzzle each morning) but even so there's a lot of ephemeral knowledge tied to a time period.

@Francis

I think a good way to approach this intellectually is to think about us now trying to do a puzzle from 2047 (not like many will have time for puzzles during the Second World Water War).

Current trivia (Author of "How I learned to love in the times of Water Wars", maybe, or winner of the 2045 Vlad&Donny award), slang (to give up one's water, say) would stump us. How many of such clues there would be would probably determine if we would be able to solve the puzzle at all.

Of course, with a puzzle from the past similar stuff is known to somebody who remembers it or has learned about it, but for many it is just as mysterious as that stuff from the future.

I wouldn't even think about approaching an American puzzle from the 90s.

My experience with hints:
if you find a word that is not an answer, you a partial credit for a hint, which shows as coloring in a third of the hints bar.
Three of them entitles you to a hint. Click it, and it will show you one of the real answers in the puzzle, outlined in dashed circles.

Answer words that can be traced out in two or more patterns,  are fairly common in Strands.

@Helen Wright 

People here do indeed say TAKE THE L here, and it may be baseball-related.  Wins and losses are a statistical category for pitchers, and they are abbreviated W and L.  Which pitcher in any game (as there are usually several) gets the win or takes the loss is statistically determined by a set of rules.  So the pitcher who loses the game statistically is said to TAKE THE L. 

Baseball is a game that is played every day of the week, for the most part, through a six-month regular season, and then, if a team is good, another month-plus of playoffs.  There are times when a team is getting beaten so badly that the manager no longer wants to use his best pitchers, so he brings in the lowest guy on the totem pole for "mopping up" duties, or even uses a non-pitcher to do this.  The manager knows that it's better to concede a game he isn't going to win anyway, and save his better pitchers for the next day.  In that case, you can say that the manager has decided to TAKE THE L and move on.  This strategy is applied to the outside world as well, to move on from something hopeless in the hopes of succeeding on something else after that.

Hope you haven't given up by this point!

@Steve L 
Thanks! You’re always so informative you’re like my personal Wikipedia, but better.
@Helen Wright “taking the L” is totally used in my circles. It’s easier to “take the L” than to “admit defeat” even though it means the same. It just feels lighter.

@Charles 

Judging by the way you end your comment, I sense you think that proper nouns in a crossword are a new thing.

Let's go back to the very first weekday NYT crossword (9/11/50).  (I chose that one because it's the same size as today's; earlier ones were all Sundays.)

The apparent theme of this puzzle (yawn!) was NYC's reservoir system.  So here are the theme answers:

1. ASHOKAN (a reservoir)
2. ESOPUS (a watershed area)
3. HOWELL (Wallace E., meteorologist associated with literal rainmaking)
4. SCHOHARIE (a reservoir)
5. CATSKILLS (where rain falls into reservoirs)
6. CROTON (a reservoir)

Other proper noun answers were (with truncated clues):

7. EPINAL (French city)
8. INGA (clued just as [Girl's name])
9. PIAVE (Italian river)
10. ADRIAN (Greenburg, Hollywood designer)
11. NEILSON (past Smith College president)
12. LETT (Latvia native)
13. EAST SIDER (Manhattan denizen)
14. HOPALONG (Cassidy, kids' idol)
15. OPEL (German car)
16. LODGE (Henry Cabot, senator)
17. MAE ([Miss Murray or Miss West])
18. EASTON (Pa. city)
19. TRENT (English river)
20. ITO (clued just as [Japanese name])
21. OMA (Lee, heavyweight boxer)
22. ETO (Where Eisenhower commanded)

Bracketed clues are verbatim.

In case you think this is a fluke, more to come in a reply.

@Steve L 

To prove the above was not a fluke, here are some answers from Will Shortz's first weekday puzzle (11/22/93):

1. RATSO (Rizzo)
2. ANA (Santa ___)
3. AIMEE [Actress Anouk]
4. NIECE (Clued as Caroline Schlossberg's relationship to Ted Kennedy)
5. CASS (Big Mama)
6. SKIP TO MY LOU [Traditional tune]
7. REASONER ([Logical newsman?], an allusion to Harry
8. MAME [Jerry Herman composition]
9. PIETA [Michelangelo masterpiece]
10. HORACE [Journalist Greeley]
11. IKE [Tina's ex]
12. WHITE (Byron)
13. TAIWAN [Taipei's land]
14. OAHU [Honolulu locale]
15. LEONA (Hotelier Leona)
16. ATHENA [Daughter of Zeus]
17. THU [Calendar abbr.]
18. CARTA [Magna ___]
19. ACLU [Rights grp.]
20. HELEN (Actress Hayes)
21. DOS [MS follower?]
22. TYNE (Newcastle-upon-____)
23. LEO [Name of 13 popes]
24. MUPPET (Oscar the Grouch)
25. ELAINE ("Seinfeld" character)
26. MET [Strawberry, once] (Darryl)
27. AT ALL ["Any Time ___" (Beatles tune)]
28. MARIO (Racer Andretti)
29. HEEP ["David Copperfield" character]
30. TKO [Foreman stat]

Of course, a few of these proper nouns are in the clue, not the answer, but most are in the answer.  And many of them (WHITE, MET, AT ALL, etc.) don't have to be clued as proper nouns, but they are.

So you may not like proper nouns in your puzzle, but I don't think they're going anywhere.
@Steve L Here are the xwordinfo.com links: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=9/11/1950 https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=11/22/1993

@Charles - As near as I can tell, most people just use the word "trivia" to demean anything in a crossword  that THEY don't know, as a means of making themselves feel better about it, rather than trying to learn something new. 

Frankly, almost ALL entries in a crossword could be considered "trivia" (the actual meaning of the word, not just an epithet used to demean stuff the solver just doesn't like). The exceptions would be theme entries, which often don't make any sense other than in the context of their themes.

@CaptainQuahog 

What you said.  :)

I still use the word "obscure" for stuff that is really out there, though I stopped using it in this forum due to the resulting attacks.  Trivia is the lifeblood of this game, but some items really verge on the edge of obscurity to me.  Lay for ballad, as one recent example....

@Jane Wheelaghan 

It’s a subculture thing. I just shouted out to my wife:

“Ted Williams’ number?”
“Nine!”
Carl Yazstremski’s?”
“Eight!”
Mickey Matle’s?”
“Seven!”

Before football (the U.S. kind), baseball was the national game.  Doris Kearns Goodwin wrote a book, ‘Wait Till Next Year,” about growing up in 1950s NY. It reflected a lot of what my mom told me of her childhood in Brooklyn and Queens in the 30s and 40s. A lot of it focused on her relationship with her father and how they bonded over their team, the Dodgers, rivals of the Giants and Yankees, and how loyalties followed neighborhood lines. My wife grew up in Boston, another rival of the Yankees. Knowing the jersey numbers of your heroes, and their rivals, was a serious thing.
